title: CycloneDX Cryptography Model
$comment: OWASP CycloneDX is an Ecma International standard (ECMA-424) developed in collaboration between the OWASP Foundation and Ecma Technical Committee 54 (TC54). The standard is published under a royalty-free patent policy. This JSON schema is the reference implementation and is licensed under the Apache License 2.0.

cryptoProperties.title: Cryptographic Properties
cryptoProperties.description: Cryptographic assets have properties that uniquely define them and that make them actionable for further reasoning. As an example, it makes a difference if one knows the algorithm family (e.g. AES) or the specific variant or instantiation (e.g. AES-128-GCM). This is because the security level and the algorithm primitive (authenticated encryption) are only defined by the definition of the algorithm variant. The presence of a weak cryptographic algorithm like SHA1 vs. HMAC-SHA1 also makes a difference.

assetType.title: Asset Type
assetType.description: Cryptographic assets occur in several forms. Algorithms and protocols are most commonly implemented in specialized cryptographic libraries. They may, however, also be 'hardcoded' in software components. Certificates and related cryptographic material like keys, tokens, secrets or passwords are other cryptographic assets to be modelled.

meta:enum.algorithm: Mathematical function commonly used for data encryption, authentication, and digital signatures.
meta:enum.certificate: An electronic document that is used to provide the identity or validate a public key.
meta:enum.protocol: A set of rules and guidelines that govern the behavior and communication with each other.
meta:enum.related-crypto-material: Other cryptographic assets related to algorithms, certificates, and protocols such as keys and tokens.

algorithmProperties.title: Algorithm Properties
algorithmProperties.description: Additional properties specific to a cryptographic algorithm.

primitive.title: primitive
primitive.description: Cryptographic building blocks used in higher-level cryptographic systems and protocols. Primitives represent different cryptographic routines: deterministic random bit generators (drbg, e.g. CTR_DRBG from NIST SP800-90A-r1), message authentication codes (mac, e.g. HMAC-SHA-256), blockciphers (e.g. AES), streamciphers (e.g. Salsa20), signatures (e.g. ECDSA), hash functions (e.g. SHA-256), public-key encryption schemes (pke, e.g. RSA), extended output functions (xof, e.g. SHAKE256), key derivation functions (e.g. pbkdf2), key agreement algorithms (e.g. ECDH), key encapsulation mechanisms (e.g. ML-KEM), authenticated encryption (ae, e.g. AES-GCM) and the combination of multiple algorithms (combiner, e.g. SP800-56Cr2).

meta:enum.drbg: Deterministic Random Bit Generator (DRBG) is a type of pseudorandom number generator designed to produce a sequence of bits from an initial seed value. DRBGs are commonly used in cryptographic applications where reproducibility of random values is important.
meta:enum.mac: In cryptography, a Message Authentication Code (MAC) is information used for authenticating and integrity-checking a message.
meta:enum.block-cipher: A block cipher is a symmetric key algorithm that operates on fixed-size blocks of data. It encrypts or decrypts the data in block units, providing confidentiality. Block ciphers are widely used in various cryptographic modes and protocols for secure data transmission.
meta:enum.stream-cipher: A stream cipher is a symmetric key cipher where plaintext digits are combined with a pseudorandom cipher digit stream (keystream).
meta:enum.signature: In cryptography, a signature is a digital representation of a message or data that proves its origin, identity, and integrity. Digital signatures are generated using cryptographic algorithms and are widely used for authentication and verification in secure communication.
meta:enum.hash: A hash function is a mathematical algorithm that takes an input (or 'message') and produces a fixed-size string of characters, which is typically a hash value. Hash functions are commonly used in various cryptographic applications, including data integrity verification and password hashing.
meta:enum.pke: Public Key Encryption (PKE) is a type of encryption that uses a pair of public and private keys for secure communication. The public key is used for encryption, while the private key is used for decryption. PKE is a fundamental component of public-key cryptography.
meta:enum.xof: An XOF is an extendable output function that can take arbitrary input and creates a stream of output, up to a limit determined by the size of the internal state of the hash function that underlies the XOF.
meta:enum.kdf: A Key Derivation Function (KDF) derives key material from another source of entropy while preserving the entropy of the input.
meta:enum.key-agree: In cryptography, a key-agreement is a protocol whereby two or more parties agree on a cryptographic key in such a way that both influence the outcome.
meta:enum.kem: A Key Encapsulation Mechanism (KEM) algorithm is a mechanism for transporting random keying material to a recipient using the recipient's public key.
meta:enum.ae: Authenticated Encryption (AE) is a cryptographic process that provides both confidentiality and data integrity. It ensures that the encrypted data has not been tampered with and comes from a legitimate source. AE is commonly used in secure communication protocols.
meta:enum.combiner: A combiner aggregates many candidates for a cryptographic primitive and generates a new candidate for the same primitive.
meta:enum.key-wrap: Key-wrap is a cryptographic technique used to securely encrypt and protect cryptographic keys using algorithms like AES.

algorithmFamily.title: Algorithm Family
algorithmFamily.description: A valid algorithm family identifier. If specified, this value shall be one of the enumeration of valid algorithm Family identifiers defined in the `cryptography-defs.schema.json` subschema.

parameterSetIdentifier.title: Parameter Set Identifier
parameterSetIdentifier.description: An identifier for the parameter set of the cryptographic algorithm. Examples: in AES128, '128' identifies the key length in bits, in SHA256, '256' identifies the digest length, '128' in SHAKE128 identifies its maximum security level in bits, and 'SHA2-128s' identifies a parameter set used in SLH-DSA (FIPS205).

ellipticCurve.title: Elliptic Curve
ellipticCurve.description: The specific underlying Elliptic Curve (EC) definition employed which is an indicator of the level of security strength, performance and complexity. If specified, this value shall be one of the enumeration of valid elliptic curves identifiers defined in the `cryptography-defs.schema.json` subschema.

executionEnvironment.title: Execution Environment
executionEnvironment.description: The target and execution environment in which the algorithm is implemented in.

meta:enum.software-plain-ram: A software implementation running in plain unencrypted RAM.
meta:enum.software-encrypted-ram: A software implementation running in encrypted RAM.
meta:enum.software-tee: A software implementation running in a trusted execution environment.
meta:enum.unknown: The execution environment is not known.

implementationPlatform.title: Implementation platforms
implementationPlatform.description: The target platforms for which the algorithm is implemented. The implementation can be 'generic', running on any platform or for a specific platform.

items.title: Platform
items.description: The target platform for the implementation.

certificationLevel.title: Certification Level
certificationLevel.description: The certification that the implementation of the cryptographic algorithm has received, if any. Certifications include revisions and levels of FIPS 140 or Common Criteria of different Extended Assurance Levels (CC-EAL).

meta:enum.unknown: The certification level is not known

mode.title: Mode
mode.description: The mode of operation in which the cryptographic algorithm (block cipher) is used.

meta:enum.ccm: Counter with cipher block chaining message authentication code
meta:enum.unknown: The mode of operation is not known

padding.title: Padding
padding.description: The padding scheme that is used for the cryptographic algorithm.

meta:enum.pkcs5: Public Key Cryptography Standard: Password-Based Cryptography
meta:enum.pkcs7: Public Key Cryptography Standard: Cryptographic Message Syntax
meta:enum.pkcs1v15: Public Key Cryptography Standard: RSA Cryptography v1.5
meta:enum.unknown: The padding scheme is not known

cryptoFunctions.title: Cryptographic functions
cryptoFunctions.description: The cryptographic functions implemented by the cryptographic algorithm.

classicalSecurityLevel.title: classical security level
classicalSecurityLevel.description: The classical security level that a cryptographic algorithm provides (in bits).

nistQuantumSecurityLevel.title: NIST security strength category
nistQuantumSecurityLevel.description: The NIST security strength category as defined in https://csrc.nist.gov/projects/post-quantum-cryptography/post-quantum-cryptography-standardization/evaluation-criteria/security-(evaluation-criteria). A value of 0 indicates that none of the categories are met.

secProperties.title: Security Properties
secProperties.description: Formal guarantees about an algorithm's resistance to specific adversarial capabilities under a defined threat model. Example: Key Encapsulation Mechanisms (KEMs) may target IND-CPA or IND-CCA security; choosing IND-CCA impacts safe use in settings with active/chosen-ciphertext attacks.

certificateProperties.title: Certificate Properties
certificateProperties.description: Properties for cryptographic assets of asset type 'certificate'.

serialNumber.title: Serial Number
serialNumber.description: The serial number is a unique identifier for the certificate issued by a CA.

subjectName.title: Subject Name
subjectName.description: The subject name for the certificate.

issuerName.title: Issuer Name
issuerName.description: The issuer name for the certificate.

notValidBefore.title: Not Valid Before
notValidBefore.description: The date and time according to ISO-8601 standard from which the certificate is valid.

notValidAfter.title: Not Valid After
notValidAfter.description: The date and time according to ISO-8601 standard from which the certificate is not valid anymore.

certificateFileExtension.title: Certificate File Extension
certificateFileExtension.description: The file extension of the certificate.

fingerprint.title: Certificate Fingerprint
fingerprint.description: The fingerprint is a cryptographic hash of the certificate excluding it's signature.

certificateState.title: Certificate Lifecycle State
certificateState.description: The certificate lifecycle is a comprehensive process that manages digital certificates from their initial creation to eventual expiration or revocation. It typically involves several stages.

state.title: State
state.description: A pre-defined state in the certificate lifecycle.

meta:enum.pre-activation: The certificate has been issued by the issuing certificate authority (CA) but has not been authorized for use.
meta:enum.active: The certificate may be used to cryptographically protect information, cryptographically process previously protected information, or both.
meta:enum.deactivated: Certificates in the deactivated state shall not be used to apply cryptographic protection but, in some cases, may be used to process cryptographically protected information.
meta:enum.suspended: The use of a certificate may be suspended for several possible reasons.
meta:enum.revoked: A revoked certificate is a digital certificate that has been invalidated by the issuing certificate authority (CA) before its scheduled expiration date.

reason.title: Reason
reason.description: A reason for the certificate being in this state.

name.title: State
name.description: The name of the certificate lifecycle state.

description.title: Description
description.description: The description of the certificate lifecycle state.

reason.title: Reason
reason.description: A reason for the certificate being in this state.

creationDate.title: Creation Date
creationDate.description: The date and time (timestamp) when the certificate was created or pre-activated.

activationDate.title: Activation Date
activationDate.description: The date and time (timestamp) when the certificate was activated.

deactivationDate.title: Deactivation Date
deactivationDate.description: The date and time (timestamp) when the related certificate was deactivated.

revocationDate.title: Revocation Date
revocationDate.description: The date and time (timestamp) when the certificate was revoked.

destructionDate.title: Destruction Date
destructionDate.description: The date and time (timestamp) when the certificate was destroyed.

certificateExtensions.title: Certificate Extensions
certificateExtensions.description: A certificate extension is a field that provides additional information about the certificate or its use. Extensions are used to convey additional information beyond the standard fields.

meta:enum.basicConstraints: Specifies whether a certificate can be used as a CA certificate or not.
meta:enum.keyUsage: Specifies the allowed uses of the public key in the certificate.
meta:enum.extendedKeyUsage: Specifies additional purposes for which the public key can be used.
meta:enum.subjectAlternativeName: Allows inclusion of additional names to identify the entity associated with the certificate.
meta:enum.authorityKeyIdentifier: Identifies the public key of the CA that issued the certificate.
meta:enum.subjectKeyIdentifier: Identifies the public key associated with the entity the certificate was issued to.
meta:enum.authorityInformationAccess: Contains CA issuers and OCSP information.
meta:enum.certificatePolicies: Defines the policies under which the certificate was issued and can be used.
meta:enum.crlDistributionPoints: Contains one or more URLs where a Certificate Revocation List (CRL) can be obtained.
meta:enum.signedCertificateTimestamp: Shows that the certificate has been publicly logged, which helps prevent the issuance of rogue certificates by a CA. Log ID, timestamp and signature as proof.

commonExtensionValue.title: Value
commonExtensionValue.description: The value of the certificate extension.

oneOf.title: Custom Extensions
oneOf.description: Custom extensions may convey application-specific or vendor-specific data not covered by standard extensions. The structure and semantics of custom extensions are typically defined outside of public standards. CycloneDX leverages properties to support this capability.

customExtensionName.title: Name
customExtensionName.description: The name for the custom certificate extension.

customExtensionValue.title: Value
customExtensionValue.description: The description of the custom certificate extension.

relatedCryptoMaterialProperties.title: Related Cryptographic Material Properties
relatedCryptoMaterialProperties.description: Properties for cryptographic assets of asset type: `related-crypto-material`.

type.title: relatedCryptoMaterialType
type.description: The type for the related cryptographic material.

meta:enum.private-key: The confidential key of a key pair used in asymmetric cryptography.
meta:enum.public-key: The non-confidential key of a key pair used in asymmetric cryptography.
meta:enum.secret-key: A key used to encrypt and decrypt messages in symmetric cryptography.
meta:enum.key: A piece of information, usually an octet string, which, when processed through a cryptographic algorithm, processes cryptographic data.
meta:enum.ciphertext: The result of encryption performed on plaintext using an algorithm (or cipher).
meta:enum.signature: A cryptographic value that is calculated from the data and a key known only by the signer.
meta:enum.digest: The output of the hash function.
meta:enum.initialization-vector: A fixed-size random or pseudo-random value used as an input parameter for cryptographic algorithms.
meta:enum.nonce: A random or pseudo-random number that can only be used once in a cryptographic communication.
meta:enum.seed: The input to a pseudo-random number generator. Different seeds generate different pseudo-random sequences.
meta:enum.salt: A value used in a cryptographic process, usually to ensure that the results of computations for one instance cannot be reused by an attacker.
meta:enum.shared-secret: A piece of data known only to the parties involved, in a secure communication.
meta:enum.tag: A message authentication code (MAC), sometimes known as an authentication tag, is a short piece of information used for authenticating and integrity-checking a message.
meta:enum.additional-data: An unspecified collection of data with relevance to cryptographic activity.
meta:enum.password: A secret word, phrase, or sequence of characters used during authentication or authorization.
meta:enum.credential: Establishes the identity of a party to communication, usually in the form of cryptographic keys or passwords.
meta:enum.token: An object encapsulating a security identity.
meta:enum.unknown: The type of cryptographic asset is not known.

id.title: ID
id.description: The unique identifier for the related cryptographic material.

state.title: State
state.description: The key state as defined by NIST SP 800-57.

creationDate.title: Creation Date
creationDate.description: The date and time (timestamp) when the related cryptographic material was created.

activationDate.title: Activation Date
activationDate.description: The date and time (timestamp) when the related cryptographic material was activated.

updateDate.title: Update Date
updateDate.description: The date and time (timestamp) when the related cryptographic material was updated.

expirationDate.title: Expiration Date
expirationDate.description: The date and time (timestamp) when the related cryptographic material expires.

value.title: Value
value.description: The associated value of the cryptographic material.

size.title: Size
size.description: The size of the cryptographic asset (in bits).

format.title: Format
format.description: The format of the related cryptographic material (e.g. P8, PEM, DER).

securedBy.title: Secured By
securedBy.description: The mechanism by which the cryptographic asset is secured by.

fingerprint.title: Fingerprint
fingerprint.description: The fingerprint is a cryptographic hash of the asset.

keyUsage.title: Key Usage
keyUsage.description: Defines the permitted cryptographic usage for the asset.

protocolProperties.title: Protocol Properties
protocolProperties.description: Properties specific to cryptographic assets of type: `protocol`.

meta:enum.unknown: The protocol type is not known

cipherSuites.title: Cipher Suites
cipherSuites.description: A list of cipher suites related to the protocol.

ikev2TransformTypes.title: IKEv2 Transform Types
ikev2TransformTypes.description: The IKEv2 transform types supported (types 1-4), defined in [RFC 7296 section 3.3.2](https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc7296.html#section-3.3.2), and additional properties.

ke.title: Key Exchange Methods (KE)
ke.description: Transform Type 4: Key Exchange Method (KE) per [RFC 9370](https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc9370.html), formerly called Diffie-Hellman Group (D-H).

esn.title: Extended Sequence Number (ESN)
esn.description: Specifies if an Extended Sequence Number (ESN) is used.

oid.title: OID
oid.description: The object identifier (OID) of the cryptographic asset.

name.title: Common Name
name.description: A common name for the cipher suite.

algorithms.title: Related Algorithms
algorithms.description: A list of algorithms related to the cipher suite.

items.title: Algorithm reference
items.description: The bom-ref to algorithm cryptographic asset.

identifiers.title: Cipher Suite Identifiers
identifiers.description: A list of common identifiers for the cipher suite.

tlsGroups.title: TLS Groups
tlsGroups.description: A list of TLS named groups (formerly known as curves) for this cipher suite. These groups define the parameters for key exchange algorithms like ECDHE.

items.title: Group Name
items.description: The name of the TLS group.

tlsSignatureSchemes.title: TLS Signature Schemes
tlsSignatureSchemes.description: A list of signature schemes supported for cipher suite. These schemes specify the algorithms used for digital signatures in TLS handshakes and certificate verification.

items.title: Signature Scheme
items.description: The name of the TLS signature scheme.

name.title: Name
name.description: A name for the encryption method.

keyLength.title: Encryption algorithm key length
keyLength.description: The key length of the encryption algorithm.

algorithm.title: Algorithm reference
algorithm.description: The bom-ref to algorithm cryptographic asset.

name.title: Name
name.description: A name for the pseudorandom function.

algorithm.title: Algorithm reference
algorithm.description: The bom-ref to algorithm cryptographic asset.

name.title: Name
name.description: A name for the integrity algorithm.

algorithm.description: The bom-ref to algorithm cryptographic asset.

ikeV2Ke.title: Key Exchange Method (KE)
ikeV2Ke.description: Object representing a key exchange method (KE).

group.title: Group Identifier
group.description: A group identifier for the key exchange algorithm.

algorithm.description: The bom-ref to algorithm cryptographic asset.

ikeV2Auth.description: Object representing a IKEv2 Authentication method.

name.title: Name
name.description: A name for the authentication method.

relatedCryptographicAssets.description: A list of cryptographic assets related to this component.

relatedCryptographicAsset.description: A cryptographic assets related to this component.

mechanism.description: Specifies the mechanism by which the cryptographic asset is secured by.
